text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
the new Ryan woman where I is a pop
music duo who is responsible for a few
of my favorite singles of 2012 and this
is their debut full-length LP the two
singles that drop before this LP open in
the fall the songs that I love on this
album that I heard before this album
it seems rise pretty quick to place
these songs right at the beginning of
this new album and just follow it up
with all this new material which I
suppose sort of makes sense since these
songs were the inception of rye in a
sense but before these two songs existed
rise two members were involved in other
projects first Mike Melosh whose name I
hope I'm pronouncing correctly is an
electronic music producer he hails from
Toronto he has a few albums under his
belt who has an incredibly feminine
voice and Robin iake is a singer and
producer and they were both relatively
under the radar until they came together
with this project and songs like open
we're getting a whole ton of buzz on the
internet but what was interesting as
they kind of put the name of the project
and just the name ROI first before
themselves and make no mistake rye has
caught on because of the power of the
songs that drop before this full-length
album but still it definitely goes to
show kind of the power of a fresh face
musical elements of previous projects
from Mike and Robin show up on this LP
through electronic music soul music pop
music as well but on here you're getting
a much more refined take on these styles
it's much more sophisticated there are
moments that are very very baroque
touched gently and lovingly with strings
and horns there are moments where I'm
hearing some jazzy woodwinds as well
there are moments where it kind of
reminds me of Jesse where a little bit
or has a bit of that throwback flavor of
the latest destroyer full-length and
sort of gender bends in the way that
perfume genius or
today and the Johnsons sometimes do
however in comparison to those two
artists I will say that Riya is way more
subtle way more soft just much more
smooth and pleasant on the ears silky
its buttery it's like fresh ice cream
there is a certain kind of sexiness that
right rise to push forward on on nearly
every track here it's a youthful
sexiness that is simultaneously unsure
of itself at times feeling a little shy
especially from the vocals it's
basically the dorm room lovemaking
soundtrack that will be pumped through
many a laptop speaker for the duration
of this year RIE is really good at
conjuring sexy sensations but there are
times when I feel like maybe they don't
bring too much to the table other than
that because when it comes to subject
matter and sound and songwriting this LP
can get a little Sammy Sammy and it's
not necessarily because I feel like
there's no talent here in this project I
feel like there's an incredible amount
of potential I just think that RIE can
get a little lacks here and there on
some of the songs because maybe the
sensuality that they want to convey to
their listeners come so easily there are
some tracks where I sense some real
ambition coming from this project like
on the opening of the track open which
ascends the album so high into the sky
with horns and strings it's a beautiful
introduction it's inspiring much more
inspiring than some of these slightly
lethargic dance grooves to come
afterwards and the song the fall which I
definitely think could have gotten away
because it is such a good song could
have gotten away with just putting the
bass groove the drums and the piano out
there and sticking with that instead RIE
covers this song very sweetly wrapping
it like a ribbon with strings and horns
that pop up so subtly throughout the
track it's beautiful now honestly these
two tracks that start the album off are
really as awesome as the album gets when
it comes to this particular vibe I feel
like there are a lot of songs that come
afterwards that try to continue the same
theme but to varying degrees of success
like the song last dance which comes
right after
the song has all the synthesizer horns I
think their synthesizer Lawrence they
sound like it and in comparison to some
of the horns that come on the previous
tracks they feel so measly and when I
have our voice on this track and others
is interestingly androgynous you know
definitely has a personality it has a
sound and he is an able singer I mean he
has no issue with pitch or anything like
that
his voice is pleasant but it's very rare
that he actually pulls emotion from a
place that feels really fiery or
passionate the moment where you hear him
saying make note to me that's like
really about the fiery ISTE gets on the
whole LP some of his vocalizations at
the end of the track shed for blood
which has this abrupt ending to it that
I didn't really care for are nice but as
some of the tracks on this help you get
a little simpler get a little more
stripped back instrumentally they're not
as decked out in strings and horns no
doesn't really fill in the gaps with any
incredibly moving vocal performances he
seems to be just as quiet sort of
coloring things lightly just as if he
were a piece of instrumentation in the
background this doesn't lead to any
terrible tracks on the LP but it just
makes many of the songs here kind of
agreeable breezy in one ear and out the
other the only song that I really
disliked was three days which had this
synth groove to it and then them just
not interesting enough to be replayed
and replayed in the way that it was had
a bit of blue-eyed soul to it a bit of
disco to it the track I mean I actually
prefer the beauty and the spaciousness
of the song one of those summer days
which heads away from the dance grooves
it's just these lone guitar chords with
just a little bit of sense dancing
around in the background subtly and in
comparison to some of the more sleek and
sensual songs it's much sadder much more
there's pretty on a track with this
emotions and they've our very shy vocals
go over so much better and my other
favorite track on this LP has got to be
the closer the title track which has
these awesome progressive synth
arpeggios all over the place it's like
as inspiring as the opening track
again it feels like I'm ascending but
this time up into space the horns are
stellar on this track - it's really
wondrous ending it has the inspiring
wonder that I wish was a little bit more
consistent throughout this LP because I
feel like I get hit in the beginning and
I get hit again in the end and the whole
trip in the middle is just not that
memorable there is a lot of potential
here this album is produced really well
the singing is good the grooves are
there but sometimes the songwriting and
the vocal performances can be a little
underwhelming I feel like Wray wants to
appeal constantly to this very vague
sense of steam eNOS it's like they want
to get sexy without getting hot I'm
really kind of feeling a light too
decent six on this thing if you've given
it a listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it rye woman forever
